Line 6: Line 6:  
'''Ethics''' (via [[Latin]] ''{{lang|la|ethica}}'' from the [[Ancient Greek]] {{lang|grc|ἠθική [φιλοσοφία]}} "moral philosophy", from the [[adjective]] of {{lang|grc|[[ἤθος]]}} ''ēthos'' "custom, [[Habit (psychology)|habit]]"), a major branch of [[philosophy]], is the study of [[Value theory|value]]s and [[Custom (law)|custom]]s of a person or group. It covers the [[Philosophical analysis|analysis]] and employment of [[concept]]s such as [[right]] and [[wrong]], [[good and evil]], and [[moral responsibility|responsibility]]. It is divided into three primary areas: ''meta-ethics'' (the study of the concept of ethics), ''normative ethics'' (the study of how to determine ethical values), and ''applied ethics'' (the study of the use of ethical values).
 
'''Ethics''' (via [[Latin]] ''{{lang|la|ethica}}'' from the [[Ancient Greek]] {{lang|grc|ἠθική [φιλοσοφία]}} "moral philosophy", from the [[adjective]] of {{lang|grc|[[ἤθος]]}} ''ēthos'' "custom, [[Habit (psychology)|habit]]"), a major branch of [[philosophy]], is the study of [[Value theory|value]]s and [[Custom (law)|custom]]s of a person or group. It covers the [[Philosophical analysis|analysis]] and employment of [[concept]]s such as [[right]] and [[wrong]], [[good and evil]], and [[moral responsibility|responsibility]]. It is divided into three primary areas: ''meta-ethics'' (the study of the concept of ethics), ''normative ethics'' (the study of how to determine ethical values), and ''applied ethics'' (the study of the use of ethical values).
    −
